questions.question_text:
Your Session Border Controller is configured as the source and destination for all signaling messages and media streams coming into and leaving the providers network.
Which two SIP functions does it provide? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer B, Just the delete-config command will do that.

comments.content: You still need to reboot to return SBC to default state. Answer E

choices.A: press the reset button on the front panel
choices.E: issue the delete-config and reboot commands

questions.question_text: To return the Session Border Controller configuration to a known, factory default state, you must____________.
Which statement is true about Session Border Controller architectures and realm bridging?

choices.D: The Peering architecture focuses on the border point between two different service provider networks and their realms.
choices.C: The Access-backbone architecture focuses on the border point between two backbone realms.
choices.B: The Hosted IP architecture focuses on the border point between one enterprise network realm and one service provider network realm.
choices.A: The Hosted NAT Traversal (HNT) architecture focuses on the border point between two different service provider networks, both in the home realm.
choices.E: The Gateway architecture Focuses on the border point between one enterprise network realm and one service provider network realm.

discussion.content:
Answer C
no command involved select delete and done

choices.C: The deletion takes effect immediately in the saved configuration.
choices.A: The deletion is lost on immediate reboot.
choices.B: The deletion is reflected when viewing the running configuration.
choices.D: The deletion always requires a reboot to take effect.

questions.question_text:
You used the no command to delete a configuration element.
Which statement is true?

discussion.content: Correct answers are A and E.
I think the correct one is C and E

choices.B: Navigate to the session-agent configuration element and set the ip-address parameter to the IP address of your trusted User Agent (UA).
choices.D: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to all.
choices.A: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to realm-prefix.
choices.E: Navigate to the realm-config configuration element and set the addr-prefix parameter to the IP subnet of your trusted User Agents (UAs).
choices.C: Navigate to the sip-port configuration element and set the allow-anonymous parameter to agents-only.

questions.question_text:
You are configuring access rules in a Session Border Controller Peering architecture.
Which two configuration steps are required to allow access only from User Agents (UAs) in a specific IP subnet? (Choose two.)
